ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to code agents that would play games well, building up to AlphaGo and AlphaGo Zero.
Combinatorial game theory, classical game theory, and computational intelligence in designing agents that play board games
Lot of game theoretic insight and applications towards programming these.
A lot of algorithms used to play tabletop games, the math behind them, and their implementation

Lots of game AI topics which reside in the field of econ and math, ranging from math algos to econ agents to neural networks. Also learned a variety of classical board and video games and history regarding them. I know how to approach problems with AI design now!
Learned how to play simple games and various computational strategies to beat games.
AI, game theory, concepts like minimax
Game theory and algos for building agents for games
I gained python skill and some understanding of key algorithms for making agents for games.

I learned a lot of foundational topics about game AI and general ML that was applicable to games. I also learned a bit about game theory. It was really cool seeing how these topics were applied to games that I have played as a child. I also liked the progression and how many things built off one another. I also liked how this class more stressed conceptual understanding over granular code implementation and thought the PSETS were fair.
Games, algorithms to solve games
I learned a lot about how computers are able to solve games and the different types of algorithms used to solve games.
I learned various algorithms for artificial intelligence development with application to games like Yahtzee and Connect 4.

I learned some basic Game theory, how to program agents to play games, and how to solve games that are solvable. I learned the theory behind making agents that can play and get better at games, using data structures to facilitate these algorithms, and even some machine learning. Games was a really awesome class that covered a really wide breadth of topics!
Learned about different techniques used to efficiently train AI game agents.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Fun course

Strengths: Content is very interesting, Professor Glenn is a great professor and really into the material, and the tests and assignments are fair. Weaknesses: Some parts of the assignments could get tedious at times, particularly the last 2, where it's hard to get a consistent test on how well your program is performing, and much of the assignment turns to into making tiny optimizations.

You'll learn each topic in depth and thoroughly understand how it works, though for some hard math concepts the proofs are skipped. But you'll usually learn it better if you review the slides and trace the pseudocodes manually. The in class visualizations are pretty helpful too.
The grading policy is quite tough, and some of the homeworks are too vague.

Strengths: Glenn is passionate about this subject and it shows! The content isn't super engaging to begin with, but he keeps it relatively interesting. Math can be difficult to parse at times as a non-math girlie

Weaknesses: 9am lecture oop, psets aren't bad but it's still a cs class lol

Strengths: Professor Glenn is super passionate about the content of this class. I think it's his bread and butter. As such, he keeps it entertaining and fun. I enjoyed the content of this class and really wish I had been more engaged and dedicated more time to the course

Weaknesses: I often couldn't follow the different algorithms, but this might have just been a function of my relatively weaker comp sci background. I had some difficulty implementing said algos on psets. I also do wish some of the psets went beyond just implementing algos, but in a way that wouldn't require even more work

Strengths: Great topics and content and Professor Glenn is really nice and funny
Weaknesses: 9am is tough, recordings cut off near the end (I assume their is a time limit, but the professor continues talking after the video cuts)

Psets were interesting and short, but the midterms were hard to prepare for. They dont count for much, but maybe getting rid of the midterms and assigning quizzes or responses in the homework would be better.
Strengths: The PSets were fun to do and a really interesting challenge.

Professor Glenn and Jarred were strengths, always providing support and assistance whenever needed. Professor Glenn was very responsive, corrected mistakes when they were made, and was clearly passionate about what he was teaching. A math background is recommended for this course.

Very manageable workload and interesting variety of programming assignments. I wish it went a little bit deeper into neural networks and included a programming assignment on it, but I understand why we didn't cover those topics as thoroughly.

Strengths: This course had some amazing assignments that were super super fun, and the exams were mostly fair. The topics were super interesting and taught super well and lectures were fun!

I can't really think of any weaknesses honestly, this class was super fun and I highly recommend it!

Strengths: Learned a lot about the space and the projects helped to solidify understanding of certain techniques.

Weaknesses: Walked away from the class with understanding of different techniques, but not too much on how to apply them in a real world setting. It seems that a lot of the actual applications in the modern day require a lot of discretion and there are a variety of nuances to applying different techniques, and I wish there was more "case study" kind of lectures to give that perspective. Overall more of a minor suggestion than a weakness though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
Yes I would recommend this to anyone who needs a CS elective, as the workload is reasonable and the material is interesting.
I strongly recommend this as a fun computer science elective, though on the easier side.

Yes, if you're interested in games and strategies to use computers to play them. It's important to note that this class is mostly about board games and card games (think Yahtzee or Connect 4) and doesn't go over video games or other more complicated games.

YESSSSSSSSSSS! It's not just about games, but a way of problem solving. These games can translate to real life and continuous state problems etc. You learn so many math, econ, and AI concepts that they can be applied to a variety of stuff. Plus the homework isn't difficult since you are coding pseudocode with less than 30 lines per assignment (generally). Plus you get to play games as Glenn walk you through it during class. Really really fun.
I personally didn't enjoy it. It was most definitely not a gut, but the content is interesting for many.
I would! Interesting, medium-level CS class
Yes, if you're intrigued by the content of the class!!

I took this class because I needed to for my major, but looking back -- this is a very interesting class to take regardless. I was taking this with econometrics and a lot of the topics overlapped and I felt that this class gave me a really good understanding of the foundations of game theory AI and machine learning techniques. It was relatively low workload day to day with PSETS due every other week, but the exams were quite tough in my opinion. Regardless, very applicable class.
Yes, you learn quite a bit.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants a relatively chill CS elective and wants to learn more about artificial intelligence.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in artificial intelligence fundamentals or that enjoys math.
Yes, this is a great class if you like thinking about strategy-based games! Easy, interesting, and fun elective for non-CS majors.

Absolutely! Glenn is wonderful and super nice, the assignments are a lot of fun, and it's a really interesting topic, with a lot of freedom for the final project so you can do pretty much anything. I enjoyed the class a lot! Definitely recommend, it's one of the most fun CS courses I've taken here.
Yes, it's a fun course that's not too taxing and if you're interesting in AI agents, you are likely to learn something new.
